item.title: Find an item in a MySQL database using Java + Tenant app
item.dc:creator: @ziplock ziplock
item.description:
@ziplock wrote:

[quote=“light232, post:3, topic:297940”][quote author=_HappyFace link=topic=394348.msg2931209#msg2931209 date=1251296423]
I just noticed while writing this that that rentProperty does not start with a capital R, and does not follow the java naming convention but i’m too lazy to change this so if you are using this you can change the rentProperty into RentProperty and change the other classes that uses this class.
But then again i know now one is going to use this ;), in that case it’s going to be more of a flaunt.

Regards HP

[/quote]
Idiot
http://www.cwu.edu/~gellenbe/javastyle/method.html[/quote]

rentProperty is a class in this app, therefor it should start with a capital.

Read full topic

item.source: Find an item in a MySQL database using Java + Tenant app

item.title: Find an item in a MySQL database using Java + Tenant app
item.dc:creator: @_HappyFace1 _HappyFace
item.description:
@_HappyFace1 wrote:

Here’s a method i wrote to find an item in a MySQL database and to show the found item. I wrote this class for someone so the text might be confusing =)

[code]public void findItemFromDatabase(){
boolean add = true;
int duplicate = 0;

	try {
		Class.forName ("com.mysql.jdbc.Driver").newInstance ();		
		Connection conn = DriverManager.getConnection (url, userName, password);

		Statement checkTenants = conn.createStatement();	
		String queryCheckTenants = "select name from tenant";
		ResultSet resultCheck = checkTenants.executeQuery(queryCheckTenants);

		String find = findTf.getText();
		while(resultCheck.next()){
			if(resultCheck.getString("Name").equals(find)){
				duplicate++;
			}
		}	

		if(duplicate>0){
			resultBtn.setVisible(true);
			resultFoundLbl.setText("Tendant found," + "\n" + "click detail(s) for more info.");
			resultFoundLbl.setVisible(true);
			searchBtn.setEnabled(false);
			findTf.setEditable(false);
			
			found = true;
			add = false;
		}
		else{
			resultBtn.setVisible(true);
			resultBtn.setEnabled(true);
			resultBtn.setText("Add tenant");
			resultFoundLbl.setText("No match found, " +"\n" + "please try again or add new tenant.");		
			resultFoundLbl.setVisible(true);
			searchBtn.setEnabled(false);
			findTf.setEditable(false);
			found = false;
			add = true;
		}
		//obsolette
		if (add){
		}
		if (!add){
		}
	} catch (InstantiationException e) {
		e.printStackTrace();
	} catch (IllegalAccessException e) {
		e.printStackTrace();
	} catch (ClassNotFoundException e) {
		e.printStackTrace();
	} catch (SQLException e) {	
		e.printStackTrace();
	}
}[/code]

[hr]

well latley i have been really busy programming a tenant application for someone, and ive know decided to release it , i know its not going to be any use here but oh well.

Download: http://www.engineeringserver.com/Software/tenant.rar (password protected)

Rar file contains:
AddTenant.java - add tenant or show details of exists.
ExistingTenant.java - show requested tentant.
FindTenant.java - find a tenant or add a new if exists.
Main.java - start application.
rentProperty.java - due to unknown requirements this is partially uncoded except for the GUI.
ShowExistingTenant.java - dummy Gui for testing purposes.

I just noticed while writing this that that rentProperty does not start with a capital R, and does not follow the java naming convention but i’m too lazy to change this so if you are using this you can change the rentProperty into RentProperty and change the other classes that uses this class.
But then again i know now one is going to use this ;), in that case it’s going to be more of a flaunt.

Regards HP

Read full topic
